content.description: Thin hands to hands. Had sling belay. Guessing this is the 5.10 mentioned in Rock and Road. Very fun and a good introduction to the area.
content.protection: Single rack from .5 to #4 camalots with three or four #1 camalots.
content.location: First big alcove down from Buck Up. Zozobra is the left corner.

content.description: Wide crack all the way up but easy to layback and stem and stay out of the crack. Can't see anchor from below.
content.protection: 3/4/5 size.
content.location: Next crack to the right of Buck Up.

content.description:
This is the obvious finger crack to the left of the offwidth New Mexico Welcome Party.  

  Shares anchor with New Mexico Welcome Party.
content.protection: Finger sizes all the way up.

content.description: A clear line that goes all the way to the top of the cliff. Fun and varied climbing through a couple of roofs.
content.protection:
0.5 to #1, a few #2s, and at least three or four #3s. A #4 or two is useful as well. One #5 for the OW section.

 A 70m just makes it down.
content.location: Starts just right of the short blocky pillar with the off widths on either side.

content.description: Starts out at #5 and goes to tight chimney. Fix und Foxi is the most successful and best known German comic series.
content.protection: One green and one blue big bro. Or climb Fix and top rope.
content.location: The right side of the short blocky pillar at the right hand side of the Rock and Road wall.

content.description:
Another Capulin classic splitter.

 Start up a wide crack that winds up and left to hands, then to fingers to a roof block. Pull around the to the right of the block to a bolted chain anchor.

 Early season there may be some packrat nesting materials on the ledge off the ground. You can either climb around it, which is not too bad, or use a short stick to push some of it off the edge so you can avoid climbing through it.
content.protection: (1) .4 to 5   a second # 3 is nice for the traverse
content.location: Right side of the A-Frame crack on the Trojan Wall SW face.

content.description: Once you figure it out, the start is equal opportunity for all finger sizes.
content.protection: Tips for fifteen feet to a slot to a right leaning thin hands crack. #0.1, #0.2 for the bottom. 0.5, 0.75 (1 or 2 each) to the base of the hands section. #1, #2 (2 or 3). One #3 for the top.
content.location: Look for the left leaning hand crack. More slippery than it appears.

content.description: Very thin dihedral; looks unlikely but climbs very well. An excellent piece protects a short run out to the anchor.
content.protection: #0 to #1, 1 each. Set medium nuts, a couple of small nuts useful.
content.location: Easy to spot because it's clean and short.

content.description: Knot your rope. Tips to fingers to hands to overhanging cupped hands. An absolutely amazing climb with a huge amount of variety.
content.protection: 0.4  0.75 (3 to 4 each).  #2 (3 each), Two #1, at least one #3.
content.location: In the first big alcove down (right) from Buck Up. This is the obvious finger crack in the right hand corner of the alcove.

content.description: Fun and intricate climbing. Starts out with broken blocky climbing below a steep and blank head wall with an obvious finger crack.
content.protection: Nuts very useful. Doubles or triples in #0.2 to #2.  Gear is good but requires a bit of fiddling.
content.location: Head for the obvious dihedral

content.description: Thin hands stemming to a very short section of OW to a single bolt protected slab move.
content.protection: Thin hands to hands to a short section of #4. #1s - #4, with one or two 0.5 and 0.75. One quickdraw.
content.location: A small alcove about fifty feet to the right of Eternal Optimist has one route on the left, one on the right.

content.description: A nice and straight forward finger crack takes you to a stout but short layback section (crux).
content.protection: A few small pieces and two or three each 0#.5 to #2. One #3 is nice up high.
content.location: Just to the left of the Title Nine/Dread Pirate corner. Next crack to the right of the Full Monty buttress.

content.description:
Arguably one of the most wild and varying routes in Capulin.  Guaranteed to have something to please everyone. 

  Chimney up a section of easy broken blocks,heading right around a corner to access the main dihedral. This leads to the base of the long steep corner.  Lose your #6 in the wide pod at the lower part of the steep corner, and charge up through a wild overhanging dihedral with great hands and a short section of fingers lieback.  Pull into the OW slot (some smaller gear in back) and squeeze up another 15 feet where you can place a #5 near the top.  A little higher and you can reach the first bolt.  At this point, you are 120' off the ground and you need to traverse left to a stance.  A series of wildly exposed mantels and pocket pulling through two more bolts gets you back to the corner.  One more small piece of gear protects a cool move that gets you to theledge with the anchor.  80m rope barely reaches with rope stretch.
content.protection: A large and varied rack, but ideally you will ditch it all before you reach the crux headwall 120' up. Here, the 12a move is bolted! Can I call this a sport climb? Camalots: double rack to #3. #4, 5 and 6 are good to have, but crafty climbers can make do without them (but be sure to pack thin to tips gear for OW and and the extra 3 for the steep corner). Save a 00 or 0 piece for the top. May want extra 2 and 3. Draws too, there are three bolts to clip and you will want them to prevent rope drag in the OW at some point.
content.location: This is the striking corner just left of Haymaker. Its an obviously huge feature that can be seen from a long way off.

content.description: Crunchy, scorched rock on the lower half of this shorty mars this little thin hands splitter. Still, it climbs alright and adds to the Capulin 5.10s list.    A few paces left of Tips Up. A finger crack leads to a small block that looks like it should come out but feels surprisingly solid. Above the block it's thin hands to hands to a hidden anchor just over the lip to the right.    If you're curious about the name, take a look up above from the anchor.
content.protection: 0.4 camalot or nut protects moves to block. 0.5 to #2 camalots above.
content.location: About five feet left of Tips Up. It seems reasonable one could access the anchors of Tips Up from this route to setup a TR on Tips Up.

content.description:
The 5.12 listed in "Rock and Road." A slight offset crack that slowly gets wider up a gently overhanging and featureless wall. The crux is tight greens through the overhanging section, with no feet. Short and straight forward; pure (and painful) crack climbing at its best.  

  The anchor is two Rawl 5 piece bolts right under the roof.
content.location: Splits the middle of the obvious blank wall.

climbs.name: Percussion Flake
climbs.fa: Jason Halladay, Josh Smith, Claudia Ihm

content.description: Hands to a nice rest on the arete out left about halfway. Then fat fists/OW to the slab finish. Shares anchor with Feeding Frenzy
content.protection: #1 to #4 camalots.
content.location: Around the corner to the right from the finger/thin hands route Feeding Frenzy. Shares anchor with Feeding Frenzy.

content.description: As for Magnum, head up the wide crack with your #6 Camalot, clip the two bolts along the way.  Place one more wide piece above and reach out right to a mailslot.  Clip another bolt above and traverse right to the layback flake that transitions to a nice hand crack.
content.protection: Take two wide pieces, one of them should be a #6 Camalot.  Then a few hand sized pieces.     3 bolts!!
content.location: Start as for Magnum, at the left side of the Trojan Wall.  2-bolt anchor

content.description: Start under a roof, reach up to the base of a splitter tight-hands crack, up to a right trending finger traverse to a large block, then bust right around the block through the same finish as The Trojan.
content.protection: Camalots   (2-3) .5 to 1
content.location: On the Trojan Wall, left A-frame route on the SW face.  Another great splitter face climb.

content.description: First that shitty hike, then this?
content.protection: Hands to #6. Can place finger size gear at the top and leave the #6. The finger crack to the left of the corner is a nice 5.12ish TR problem.
content.location: At the left of the Alcove just at the top of the Capulet/Capulin juncture.

content.description: Climbs to an interesting looking after split by a crack. It’s possible to climb the thin hands crack on the legt as well though it has some bird poop in it.
content.protection: Doubles from #0 to #1, extra #0.5-#1.
content.location: Go past Psychokiller wall and look for the crack in the arete up high.

content.description: Methedras forms the back wall of Isengard fortress. This route is tucked away in a shady corner around the back of the tower (see beta photo). It never receives sun so is good on a hot day. Fun slightly wide climbing leads to smaller stuff to an anchor.
content.location: Climb After Party Party to the ledge. Walk around the right side of the Isnengard tower and look for the obvious hand crack.

content.description: Start at the base of the left of double cracks.  Climb up through a techy crux that uses the right crack and some face holds to join the top of Achilles, only with a unique sequence to make the join.
content.protection: Camalots   (1) each red C3 to 1   double up on either .5 or 1 for the finish
content.location:
Right most route on the Trojan Wall, S-face. 

  Bolted chain anchor

climbs.name: Kev Crack
climbs.fa: A. Miller, J. Smith, K. Obrien, H. Khalsa

content.description:
This route looks a lot harder than it actually climbs.  Great jams and other interesting holds in the steep corner with overlaps.   

  Step up into a fun chimney and pop a cam above you before transitioning into the nice corner crack.  Step up onto an alcove, catch your breath, and cruise easier terrain to the anchors.
content.protection: single rack from 0.5 to #5 Camalot.  Bring an extra gold and blue camalot.  bolted anchor.
content.location: Just left of the infamous Psycho-Killers, starts in a chimney that leads to hands in a corner through steep overlaps.

content.description: Start off with your #6 until you can clip some bolts.  Head up through the remaining wide crack and head right to the anchors.
content.protection: Camalots:   1 each #1 to #6.  2 bolts on wide section, 2 bolts anchor.
content.location: On the Trojan Sector, the obvious wide crack to the left of The Odyssey.

content.description: Short and a bit crunchy but not a bad way to sample the wall for the first time.
content.protection: Hands to fingers to fat hands. One-#0.75, one #1, one #2, one #3.
content.location: Faces Sundog.

content.description: This is an extraordinary route in an extraordinary location and well worth the effort of climbing a (fun) approach pitch to get to it. The route starts on a civilized belay ledge at the base of the crack, climbs beautiful 11- fingers/thin hands to a pod where it possible to get a no hands rest below a tiny roof. The business begins with 12+ laybacking up a shallow edge for about ten feet to a jug and a quasi-rest/stem; excellent nut placement here. More 5.12 stemming and face climbing takes you to the top, past one bolt. Anchors/chains at top.
content.protection: 2 each (#0.1 - #1), optional #3 for the pod, a handful of medium nuts. Past the roof, it is possible to place two bomber nuts and one so-so nut. The so-so nut goes is in soft rock about three feet below the bolt, hence the bolt.
content.location: When you're approaching the main wall from the wash, look up and you'll see the tower on the second level of rock, directly above New Mexico Welcome Party. Climb After Party Party to reach the ledge, unrope and walk the 100 feet to the base of the tower.

content.description: The route is fantastic except for one little blip. It has 80 feet of great hands in great rock up a steep face, but the first 20 feet on soft choss approaching the wall detract some. Traverse in from the right stepping carefully, clip a couple of fixed pieces (back clean the first). The white crumbly stuff is only about 5.0 and the crack is worth the dirty walk. Be careful with a 60m rope! It would be possible to lower off the end when lowering downhill--knot the end.
content.protection: A #3 protects behind the big flake about 15 feet to the left of the start. A 0.4 or 0.5 protects the move onto the ledge to start the meat of the route. 1-#0.75, 3 each #1-2, #4 nice for the pod, #3 for the finish.
content.location: Last route on the upper wall before it folds into Capulet.

content.description:
Beautiful fingers for 40 feet to a pod, then hands. 

  Just after you think you passed the crux section, it delivers the knockout punch. 

  You can start by walking out a bushy ledge, but better to start with a dirty but easy boulder problem down and right with a simple mantle onto the starting ledge.  Good spot to belay too.
content.protection: Camalots   (2-3).3 to .4   (2) .5 to 1   (1) 2,3, can bring just one of these if you are solid on the size.
content.location: Far right side of the Upper Wall, a stunning splitter on the right side of a blunt arete.    Chain anchors

climbs.name: Glasnost Crack
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, George Perkins, Calita Quesada

content.description: A remarkably fun and moderate second pitch to either Moondog (probably the best approach) or P1 of the Full Monty. Look for the handcrack splitting the roof on the second tier of the Full Monty alcove. Good hands leads to a four or five foot #5 section below a roof. Pull the roof, punch through another roof on #2s to a nice hand crack, then face climb up an interesting and textured face, placing gear in the crack and in good horizontals.
content.protection: 1 each 0.2 to #1, 3 or 4 each (#2), 1 each #5.
content.location: In the second tier of the first big alcove on the upper wall; locate Moondog or the Full Monty; Glasnost is directly opposite Full Monty, above Moondog.

content.description: Full Monty: P1 is about 5.9, 70ft, P2 is about 5.10-, 90ft). P1 is the Half Monty; nice stemming up a broken corner. P2 is the Full Monty, which features everything you might expect to see in a climb plus a few things you probably could have done without seeing. Wide crack to a corner to a roof to a wild, featured off width chimney.
content.protection: Small gear inside the chimney (0.1 TCUs) ease the gear load. Leader will want to tunnel inside near the top for a short Harding Slot Simulator. One each 0.1 to #2. #5 and #6 nice to have. Long slings to control drag. Maybe take extra 0.1-0.2 for the chimney.
content.location: Look for the first obvious tower on the upper portion of the cliff; about 200 feet down from the shoulder of Capulet/Capulin. P2 has an obvious and very difficult looking roof which turns out to be pretty straight forward.

content.description: Two frogs were hanging out half way up (half in, half out) the right hand crack on the FA. Obvious twin finger/tips cracks about two and a half feet apart. Leaping your way up this one requires some tricky leg work.
content.protection: 0.5 to 2 (down low).

content.description: Kind of silly because its so short, but still a fun and safe way to practice off width technique.
content.protection: Can protect the finger crack of Barracuda for most of the route. An optional #6 or larger piece for the top.
content.location: The left side of the short block at the right hand side of the Rock and Road wall.

content.description: Fingers to thin hands to hands.  Shares anchor with Percussion Flake.
content.protection: #0.5 to  #2 camalots.
content.location: Short and obvious tips crack just before you turn the corner to the Rock and Road wall.

content.description: Excellent hands to fists in a very clean corner.
content.protection: Hands to 3.5/#4
content.location: The obvious clean corner at the shoulder of Capulet/Capulin.

content.description: Thin hands to hands to fat fingers layback.
content.protection: 0.5 - 0.75 for the top, #1-#2 for the bottom.
content.location: Just left of the large, perfect clean corner.

content.description: Very thin start to fun and varied climbing. Has a face climbing crux right off the ground and a power crux at the top. The offwidth to the right of the corner is the Fezzik variation. It goes at 5.10, #5 and #6.
content.protection: #0 to #2, about two each. Useful to have a #0.1 or 0.2 to protect the moves off the 3/4 way ledge.
content.location: Ten feet to the right of Title Nine; this is the obvious corner with big OW just to its right.

content.description: Interesting and extremely varied climbing. Very un-Capulin like. The gear is good, but it takes some thinking, particularly for the upper 1/3rd.
content.protection: First piece is a nut in a fantastic constriction, then interesting and varied climbing. Double rack from #0.2 to #2 with a few extras in the tips sizes. Set medium nuts.
content.location: First crack to the left of Buck Up.

content.description: Start under the big flake in the cave. We jumped up and down on it and couldnt get it to budge, so it seems pretty safe to climb over. Pretty fun, a little weird.
content.protection: Hands to #4
content.location: Just to the right of Title 9 is a cave; step in the cave and go up or climb the flare just outside the cave to get to the top of the block that takes you to the OW section.

content.description:
This route shares the first 50 feet or so of Beasts of the Northern Wild and is higher quality. There is a 5.11- crux right off the ground (well protected but think about rope drag when placing gear) which leads to a very easy ramp. The wall turns vertical again and the crack goes into a body-sized V slot/roof feature; climb into this slot (good but tricky protection) and step into the right dihedral (go left here for Beasts). Delicate 5.11 climbing with small gear (take some RPs or small nuts) leads you to a terrific ledge about 40 feet from the top. If you still have energy, keep going up the perfect acute corner. Or, build a gear belay and bring up your partner so that you can admire their technique on steep #0.75s.

 To get down, rap with a single 70 to the lower Beasts anchor, then to the ground.
content.protection: Doubles from 0 - #2, set RPs. The upper dihedral is probably best climbed with two #0.5s and four #0.75s. Possible to place a #3 right off the ledge and a #1 up high but both are optional. Slings to control rope drag.
content.location: Chokecherry starts in the same corner as Beasts of the Northern Wild and branches into the right corner about 50 feet up. This is the first corner past the big panel that contains Zozobra, Burning Man, and Tip of the Toe. While it is possible to climb the broken rock to the right to get into the corner system, the obvious finger crack start is a lot higher quality.

climbs.name: Chimney Sweep
climbs.fa: Jason Halladay, Josh Smith, Claudia Ihm

content.description: Thin hands in a corner to a couple of wider pods to an interesting chimney finish. A great variety of climbing on this one.
content.protection: #1  #3 (3-4 each). #4 useful up high.
content.location: The clean looking hand crack just before the Rock and Road wall; up in a little corner by itself.

content.description:
This is an interesting route for those in search of squeeze chimneys, but because it is on the second tier of rock above Moondog and because it has no anchor (we drilled bolts but the rock was too soft even for a half-inch sleeve bolt) it is unlikely to see much attention.  If you do go up there, start on the big ledge beneath a chimney that varies in width between 18 and 25 inches. Plug a few small pieces and then burrow into the chimney; wiggle back and forth and generally go inwards and upwards. There is a finger crack inside that you can protect. 

 We rapped off a small aspen right near the top of the route, then rapped again to get to the ground.
content.protection: A small selection of finger to hand sized pieces. Possible to place a #6 at the top.
content.location: When you're in the Sundog/Moondog area you can see the obvious big chimney in the alcove above.

content.description: A great option for warming up prior to the longer, pumpier Handyman. Shares start with Handyman. After the first ledge, stay right in the hand crack behind the large flake. Enjoy the hand jams until you reach a decent ledge. Rest up and fire the final section of fist crack leading to full-on off width. Charlie's #6 protects the mantel onto the finish ledge nicely; your #6 should work just as well.There are no anchor bolts on this route currently, as we didn't have a bolt kit. I had to top out the climb. The top out is loose and dangerous; it is not recommended. Anchor bolts will be added at the finish ledge as soon as I can get back out there.
content.protection: A couple draws for the bolts at the start, one 0.4 cam to protect after the bolts, several #2's, two #3's, one #4 (optional for fist section), one #6.
content.location: Shares start with Handyman

content.description:
The obvious right-facing corner that ends at the burnt tree, starting from a ledge 40' up, 50' left of The Trojan wall.  It is shaded by early afternoon, when those climbs are in the hot sun. 

  The meat of the climb is wide hands stemming in the corner, but the climbing is varied over all.  Hand cracks in R-facing corners gain 2 ledges before you reach the start of the obvious corner.  You could scramble up easy blocky loose junk to the right, to get to the corner as well.
content.protection: Up to a #4 camalot, #5 optional.   Rap off the burnt tree (this is sketchy). Be ready to leave gear or find a way to the top.

content.description: Thin hands to a crux traverse to thin hands to short wide, to short fists, to short hands. Extraordinary and quite physical.
content.protection: 0.2 - 0.75 (2 or 3 each). Traverse is 0.2. #1 - #2 (3 to 4 each), two #3.
content.location: In the middle of the wall of the first big alcove down canyon from Buck Up. Zozobra is to the left, Tip of the Toe to the right.

content.description: A wild and aesthetic line following unlikely cracks and seams, pieces together seamlessly on bomber rock with solid gear placements. Requires a fair bit of try-hard, a must-do for the bold and Adventurous. Start by spending your green C3s in a thin, unusable crack leading to a pod with a good hand jam ( an optional red C3 fits just below the jam getting you one last piece before standing up to clip the first bolt at the power crux.) Climb through two more bolts and lots of thin crack and unlikely pockets that lead you to an amazing but tricky final upper crux
content.protection: 3 each: green and red C3s (blue and purple TCUs), one each 0.4, 0.5, and purple C3(grey TCU). 0.2 camalots work well also. 4-6 draws. Has 3 bolts.
content.location: BDTH is on the Psycho Killers Sector, just right of the stubby “Und Foxi” tower. Starts atop a block with some odd hand pods that leads quickly to a thin seam in an offset right-facing corner. Hard moves through good pockets and bad feet, several rests, and an exciting and committing finish get you to the anchor atop a big ledge.

content.description: The most obvious clean dihedral on the upper wall. Good as a reference point. Pitch 1 is fun fingers and hands (5.10). Belay on a big ledge about 70 feet up. P2 is an amazing stretch of stemming and thin climbing (5.11+).
content.protection: P1 takes finger to hand sizes.  P2 #3s useful. P2: 2 or 3 each 0.4 to #2. One #3 useful for just below the single bolt. Possible to place good medium nuts.
content.location: About a third of the way down the upper wall. The most obvious clean dihedral on this wall.

content.description: Shares the first fifteen feet of climbing with Buck Up and then steps left. Beautiful climbing on bullet rock; tips to small fingers to a fun little roof. The crux is the five or six feet of slot going up to the little roof; for those with large fingers, this may well be 12+. Fired OS by Cody.
content.protection: Small gear, #0.2 to #0.75.
content.location: Find Buck Up. Buck Nasty steps left onto the slab left of Buck Up and climbs the splitter.

content.description: Called Booster Seat because the route really starts with the thin hands on top of the big block. The OW at the start is quite easy, the upper thin hands not nearly so easy. Pretty darn fun if you happen to have a #6 with you or feel OK running it out a little ways on easy wide climbing.
content.protection: Place a nut, then quickly a #6.  Upper overhanging crack is 0.75 and #1.
content.location: Shares an anchor with Chunnel and starts about fifteen feet down canyon.

climbs.name: Beasts of the Northern Wild
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Aaron Miller, Rich Strang

content.description: Fingers laybacking to thin tips to thin hands. Varied and very entertaining.
content.protection: Set TCUs, 2 or 3 each 0.5-#1, (need 3-#1s for the thin hands) one #2. Selection of small nuts useful. Save a couple of 1s for the thin hands right before the anchor.
content.location: Next corner down from the obvious Zozobra/Burning Man alcove.

content.description: Fingers next to a pillar that is easy to stem off of for the first half of the route.
content.location: The obvious finger crack at the right hand side of the Rock and Road wall.

climbs.name: Asterix and Oblelix
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Josh Payne, Jason Young

content.description: Two really fun and radically different pitches. P1 is the Obelix pitch; surprisingly accessible 5.10 wide climbing through pods with stemming possible for part of it. Hand jams at the at the tops of the pods keep it from being too difficult. P2 is the Asterix pitch; step left at the belay, and work your way up a challenging dihedral on bullet rock. Tricky 5.11. Tiny tips climbing gives way to fingers and the crux is over quickly, though the climbing remains engaging all the way up. The rock is excellent. Superb!
content.protection:
P1, 60 ft. 1 fixed pin to protect the choss at the bottom. It's a six inch pin, and the rock isn't as bad as it looks.   (2 each) #1-#4   (1 each) #5 

  P2, 60 ft.   (2-3 each) #0 to #1 (Red C3s work very well. Green C3s are a bit small).  Could use some small nuts.
content.location: About twenty feet down canyon from Haymaker; pretty much the last route on the upper wall before the rock turns to junk.

content.description: A very fun route that is only marred by a bit of crumbly 4th class scrambling to get to the base of the crack. The crux is over in the first twenty feet, and the rest of the route is fun 5.10 rambling up solid rock.
content.protection: 3 each #0.2 to #1   2 each #2   Medium nuts optional but helpful in a couple of places.
content.location: This route is almost all the way down to where the upper cliff joins the main cliff. The Haymaker ledge is probably the best landmark; from there, walk downstream 30 feet.    Start the route from the left by scrambling up some scary blocks that are a bit more solid than they look onto a ledge about fifteen feet off the ground. These did not pry off, but be careful here. Your first gear will be #0.4s in the obvious crack.

content.description: At the left of the Alcove just at the top of the Capulet/Capulin juncture.
content.protection: One finger piece, #1 - #4. Rap from the tree at the top of the crack.
content.location: At the left of the Alcove just at the top of the Capulet/Capulin juncture. This is the "prow" route in the middle of the wall.

content.description:
Enjoyable face climbing/finger crack start leads to an easy ramp following a finger crack. Hands to wide hands climbing leads to an overhanging, offset #4 camalot crux crack. The offset nature of the crack means one doesn't have to conjure up serious OW climbing.  

  Cop a rest above the overhanging crux before finishing up via an offset wide crack/chimney to a ledge and the anchor.
content.protection: Two each .5, .75, #4 camalots. One each #1, #2, #3, #5 camalots. A blue big bro or #6 for finish is nice to have. Two bolt anchor at top.
content.location:
Adiós Alemanes starts six feet left of Sundog in the dark flared crack with nice finger crack in back. The route was new in October 2013 and not listed on Josh's excellent Upper Wall mini guide. 

Mini guide for upper wall

content.description:
For those with bigger hands, this is your Achilles Heel. 

  This route would be 4-stars if it were a little longer.
content.protection: Camalots   (2-3) .5 to 1
content.location:
Left route of the S-Face of the Trojan Wall. 

  Bolted chain anchor shared with Hector.

pathTokens: Capulin Canyon and Cochiti Mesa Area Crags

content.description: The upper wall can be approached by any of any of the approaches marked on the main overview map. The majority of the routes on this wall are 100 feet or less, though there are some excellent routes that require two ropes. The easiest way to get to the wall proper is to head up the shoulder of the Capulet side canyon and the main canyon.
